title-group.article-title: Cost and cost-effectiveness analysis of point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) in obstetrics: a systematic review protocol

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Facing the profound health impacts and economic challenges posed by the high maternal mortality ratio worldwide, point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) has shown its potential to enhance diagnostic efficiency, reduce healthcare costs and improve health outcomes. However, concerns regarding the explicit and implicit costs as well as actual clinical outcomes of POCUS also exist. This systematic review protocol aims to synthesise existing evidence regarding the costs and cost-effectiveness of POCUS in obstetric care to provide a clearer understanding of its economic and clinical impact, ultimately guaranteeing global maternal and neonatal health and supporting the vision of the 2030 sustainable development goals.

sec.title: Methods and analysis
sec.p: This systematic review has been registered in Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO; CRD42024572715) and follows the Joanna Briggs Institute Manual for Evidence Synthesis and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses 2020 guidelines. A comprehensive search was conducted across eight international and Chinese databases, as well as five specialised health economics retrieval databases. Eligible studies include formal economic evaluations and cost-related analyses of POCUS in obstetrics, selected using the ‘Participants, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome and Study Design’ framework. The quality of included studies will be assessed using the Consensus Health Economic Criteria list, while data extraction will follow a standardised form based on the National Health Service Economic Evaluation Database Handbook. Narrative synthesis will be applied to summarise economic and clinical data, and, where appropriate, meta-analysis will be conducted for clinical outcomes. Heterogeneity will be assessed using Cochran’s Q test and Higgins’ I² statistic, and subgroup and meta-regression analyses will be used to explore the effect modification. All analyses will be conducted using Stata V.18.0, and a two-tailed p value of less than 0.05 will be considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: Since this systematic review will exclusively use published and publicly available data, ethical approval is not required. The findings from this study will be published in peer-reviewed journals or presented at academic conferences.

caption.title: Strengths and limitations of this study

list-item.p: This systematic review will be the first to assess both the costs and cost-effectiveness of point-of-care ultrasound in obstetric care, incorporating both economic and clinical perspectives.
A comprehensive and multilingual search strategy across international, regional and specialised health economics databases guarantees a broad evidence base.
Standardised data extraction and a rigorous quality assessment using validated tools will strengthen the reliability and transparency of the findings.
Heterogeneity in cost reporting, healthcare settings and implementation practices may limit the comparability and generalisability of results.
Meta-analysis may not be feasible for economic outcomes, requiring reliance on narrative synthesis due to the variability in cost and cost-effectiveness data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Protecting maternal health is a critical focus of the global public health agenda, with the target of reducing the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to fewer than 70 maternal deaths per 100 000 live births by 2030.1 2 Despite global efforts, maternal mortality remains persistently high. According to data from the United Nations Population Fund, an estimated 287 000 maternal deaths occurred in 2020, which corresponds to a global MMR of 223 per 100 000 live births.3 The burden of maternal mortality is concentrated in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where MMRs are more than double the global average.3 In addition to the implications for health systems and families, maternal mortality imposes a substantial financial burden, which notably delays the achievement of the sustainable development goals. In 2019, maternal mortality in LMICs was associated with an estimated welfare loss of US$36 billion, representing approximately 6% of the region’s gross domestic product.4 5

To prevent significant economic losses, obstetric complications require effective and scalable interventions to be timely and accurately diagnosed, thereby reducing MMRs in LMICs. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS), defined as the acquisition, interpretation and immediate clinical integration of ultrasonographic images by the treating physician at the bedside,6 has expanded rapidly in obstetric indications in recent years due to its great potential to reduce MMR.7 By facilitating early detection of maternal and foetal complications, POCUS offers a cost-effective intervention for improving clinical outcomes and reducing preventable deaths.8 Its utility in resource-constrained environments is further underscored by evidence from the Philippines, where task-shifting POCUS services to community health workers could effectively prevent 6.3% of maternal deaths and 14.6% of newborn deaths.9 Therefore, the use of POCUS in obstetric care has the potential to significantly enhance maternal survival and reduce the overall financial burden on the healthcare system.

In addition to reducing maternal mortality, POCUS has demonstrated the potential for economic benefits. Through rapid diagnosis, POCUS facilitates timely clinical decision-making and the early management of obstetric complications, which may help avoid costly adverse outcomes and strengthen both maternal and neonatal health.10 For example, a cost-minimisation analysis published in BMC Health Services Research showed that POCUS in early pregnancy, particularly in vaginal bleeding cases, could reduce referral to secondary healthcare, resulting in estimated savings of €110 per examination.11 In emergency care, an observational study found that the use of POCUS led to median savings of US$71.80 for patients discharged home and US$138.90 for patients presenting with specific symptoms such as flank pain without compromising patient safety outcomes.12 Therefore, these findings suggest that POCUS may serve as a cost-effective diagnostic strategy in obstetrics, contributing to improved clinical outcomes while alleviating financial pressures on healthcare systems.

While the potential for clinical and cost savings of POCUS in obstetric care has been proven, its cost-effectiveness, defined as the extent to which a healthcare intervention achieves improved clinical outcomes relative to the resources expended, remains contested. The indirect costs, such as the increased care costs caused by missed diagnoses or inappropriate clinical decisions, may undermine the perceived economic value of POCUS. In comparison to conventional ultrasound systems that are equipped with advanced imaging technologies, higher resolution and a broader range of functionalities,13 POCUS may be less reliable in detecting complex anatomical structures or subtle pathological findings, which is important in obstetrics. Thus, exclusive reliance on POCUS in obstetrics may result in missed or inaccurate diagnoses, leading to suboptimal treatment decisions and increasing the cost and clinical burden of patient care.14 15 Furthermore, the cost of training is another source of indirect costs. While POCUS devices are generally less expensive than conventional ultrasound machines, the absence of curricula,16 the inadequacy of standardised training and competency assessment17 18 and expensive face-to-face training sessions19 have placed substantial financial strain on both healthcare institutions and governments. The considerations on the invisible additional costs of POCUS underscore the necessity for comprehensive cost-effectiveness analyses that account for both the direct and indirect costs of POCUS deployment, including its potential limitations in diagnostic performance and the infrastructural investments required for sustainable implementation.

To effectively advance the application of POCUS in obstetrics and to promote maternal and neonatal health, a comprehensive review of the cost and cost-effectiveness of POCUS in obstetric care is essential. Although individual original studies have explored the costs and cost-effectiveness of POCUS in obstetric care, to date, no systematic review or other form of evidence synthesis has been conducted to aggregate and critically evaluate these findings. A preliminary search of major evidence-based registration platforms and databases, including the Cochrane Library, Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI) Evidence Synthesis and Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO), using the key search terms such as ‘Obstetrics’, ‘POCUS’, ‘Cost’ and ‘Cost-Benefit Analysis’ following the ‘Participants, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome and Study Design’ (PICOS) framework, yielded no systematic reviews or secondary research focused on this topic. The absence of methodological consistency and standardised approaches to measuring cost-effectiveness significantly limits the utility of existing evidence for stakeholders, including policymakers, health system administrators and global health donors, who must evaluate the feasibility and scalability of implementing POCUS across diverse healthcare settings. Without comparable metrics, clearly defined cost components and unified outcome indicators, decision-makers face substantial challenges in assessing whether investments in POCUS align with health system priorities, budget constraints and equity goals.

Therefore, this systematic review aims to synthesise and critically evaluate existing original studies addressing the costs and cost-effectiveness of POCUS in obstetrics to provide a clearer picture of the economic implications of POCUS and help inform policy decisions regarding its integration into routine obstetric care. Building on existing research while offering the first systematic synthesis in this area, this review aims to strengthen the evidence base for decision-making and accelerate progress towards achieving equitable, high-quality maternal and neonatal healthcare globally.

sec.title: Methods and analysis
sec.p: To ensure transparency and adherence to the established systematic review protocol, this review has been preregistered with PROSPERO (CRD42024572715). The methodology will follow the JBI Reviewers’ Manual 2014 guidelines,20 with particular reference to ‘Chapter 6: Systematic Review of Economic Evidence’. The report of findings will align with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) 2020,21 ensuring clarity, consistency and reproducibility. The development and documentation of this protocol will be guided by the PRISMA-Protocol 2015 checklist,22 23 provided as online supplemental file 1.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria
sec.p: Drawing on the methodological guidance from the JBI manual and insights gained from previous research, the inclusion and exclusion criteria have been developed using the ‘PICOS’ framework. The ‘PICOS’ framework provides a structured approach for addressing five core dimensions of the research question: Participants (P), Intervention (I), Comparison (C), Outcome (O) and Study design (S). A systematic overview of the eligibility criteria across the ‘PICOS’ framework is demonstrated in table 1.

list-item.p: Women receiving care unrelated to pregnancy (eg, general health checkups).
Women with documented medical conditions that may interfere with ultrasound imaging accuracy (eg, abdominally implanted metal devices).
Women who have not provided sufficient demographic information (eg, income level, educational background or regional distribution).
Obstetric POCUS examination for assessing the fetus, placenta and uterus, as well as for monitoring during labour and the postpartum period.
POCUS is not performed by operators whose qualifications or training background are reported.
POCUS procedures are not accompanied by a clear description of operational protocols (eg, identity of the operator, clinical setting and timing of use).
POCUS examination procedures that do not maintain reliable records.
Standard care without prenatal ultrasound examinations.
Use a combination of conventional ultrasound or standard care with other diagnostic modalities incompatible with POCUS.
Non-standardised cost data (eg, lacking currency units).
Cost reporting lacks critical transformation details (eg, year of equipment acquisition, valuation method).
Studies on the costs and/or utilisation of POCUS in obstetrics, including formal economic evaluation.
Studies discussing economic aspects of POCUS or providing relevant primary or secondary data on cost and/or utilisation.
Studies that are not directly related to the economic evaluation of POCUS in obstetrics.
Methodological descriptions related to the economic evaluation of POCUS.
Reviews focused on the economic aspects of POCUS.
Surveys on POCUS utilisation in obstetrics.
Discussions on health finance, policy or awarded grants.

sec.title: Inclusion criteria
sec.p: According to the ‘PICOS’ framework, this review includes studies involving pregnant women aged 15–49 years, encompassing both primiparous and multiparous individuals and covering various stages of the perinatal period. The intervention involves obstetric POCUS examinations, including application in foetal development, placental health, uterine conditions, the labour process and postpartum status. For comparison, studies that compare POCUS to conventional ultrasound performed with larger machines or to standard care without prenatal ultrasound examinations have been included. The outcomes of interest encompass both direct and indirect costs at the hospital and patient levels, the cost-effectiveness of POCUS and various clinical outcomes. Eligible study designs are formal economic evaluations, including cost analysis, cost-effectiveness analysis, cost-utility analysis and cost-benefit analysis that evaluate the economic impact and utilisation of POCUS in obstetric contexts. Additionally, studies that discuss economic aspects of POCUS or provide relevant primary or secondary data on cost or utilisation are also included.

sec.title: Exclusion criteria
sec.p: The exclusion criteria also follow the ‘PICOS’ framework. For the participants, studies involving women who are receiving healthcare unrelated to pregnancy, such as general medical checkups, or those with clearly documented medical conditions that may interfere with ultrasound imaging, such as abdominally implanted medical devices, will be excluded. In terms of the intervention, studies will be excluded if they fail to report the qualifications or training background of the POCUS operators, or if they do not adequately describe the procedural aspects of POCUS implementation, including details such as who performed the scan, the clinical context in which it was performed (eg, in a labour ward, antenatal clinic or emergency setting) and how the examination was conducted. Studies that lack sufficient information on how imaging results were documented, interpreted and applied in clinical decision-making will also be excluded. Regarding the comparison component, studies that use a combination of conventional ultrasound or standard care with other diagnostic modalities incompatible with POCUS will be excluded. With respect to the outcome, studies that report cost data without appropriate standardisation, such as missing currency units, unclear reference years, undefined valuation methods or lacking essential details related to cost information will be excluded. These details include the year of equipment acquisition, the basis of cost estimation or the perspective adopted in the analysis. Finally, studies that do not focus on the economic evaluation of POCUS in obstetric care will also not be considered.

sec.title: Information sources and search strategy
sec.p: The research team conducted the systematic literature search following the JBI’s three-stage search strategy.24 First, an initial exploratory search was implemented in databases such as PubMed and SinoMed to identify ‘seed references’. Based on the results of the preliminary search, a structured search strategy was developed under the predesigned eligibility criteria. This structured strategy involved three key terms, ‘pregnant woman’, ‘point-of-care ultrasound’ and ‘costs and cost-effectiveness analysis', with a combination of both subject headings and free-text terms. The search strategies and results obtained from PubMed are presented in table 2. Subsequently, a formal search was conducted across four major international databases (PubMed, Embase, Web of Science and Scopus), four Chinese databases (CNKI, Wanfang Data, CQVIP database and SinoMed) and five specialised health economics retrieval databases (EconLit with Full Text, the Health Technology Assessment Database, National Health Service (NHS) Economic Evaluation Database, EconPapers and Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Xplore Digital Library). Complete search strategies for all databases are presented in online supplemental file 2. Finally, a snowball method was employed to supplement the search by reviewing the references of the included studies.

caption.title: Search strategies and results in PubMed

tr.td: "Pregnant Women"[MeSH Terms] OR "Fetus"[MeSH Terms] OR "Infant, Newborn"[MeSH Terms] OR "Perinatal Care"[MeSH Terms] OR "Prenatal Care"[MeSH Terms] OR "Prenatal Diagnosis"[MeSH Terms] OR "Pregnancy" [MeSH Terms] OR "Delivery, Obstetric"[MeSH Terms] OR "Labor, Obstetric" [MeSH Terms] OR "Parturition"[MeSH Terms] OR "Postpartum Period"[MeSH Terms] OR "Obstetrics"[MeSH Terms] OR "Hospitals, Maternity"[MeSH Terms] OR "Birthing Centers"[MeSH Terms]

fn.p: Search date: from inception to 21 October 2024.

sec.p: All relevant studies identified in the aforementioned databases from their inception to 21 October 2024 will be included, with no restrictions on language or study type. The restrictions regarding the eligibility criteria will be applied in the subsequent study selection stage.

sec.title: Data management and data extraction
sec.p: All included studies will be imported into EndNote 20 following the removal of duplicate entries. Two independent reviewer teams screen the titles, abstracts and full texts of the studies, with all decisions and reasons for exclusion meticulously recorded. Discrepancies will be resolved through consensus or adjudicated by a third reviewer. When full texts or specific data are unavailable, corresponding authors will be contacted for clarification or missing information. A PRISMA 2020 flow diagram (figure 1) will illustrate the process of selecting studies.

caption.title: PRISMA 2020 flow diagram. This flow diagram illustrates the process of the systematic review conducted under the PRISMA 2020 guidelines. It outlines the identification, screening, eligibility and inclusion of studies based on searches conducted exclusively in databases and registers. The flow diagram provides a clear visualisation of the number of records identified, the reasons for exclusions at each stage and the final number of studies included in the systematic review. *Consider, if feasible to do so, reporting the number of records identified from each database or register searched (rather than the total number across all databases/registers). **If automation tools were used, indicate how many records were excluded by a human and how many were excluded by automation tools. Source: Page et al (2021).21 This work is licensed under CC BY 4.0. To view a copy of this licence, visit https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/. PRISMA, Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses.

sec.p: For the data extraction, this systematic review follows the standardised data extraction form as detailed and developed under the NHS Economic Evaluation Database Handbook (2007).25 According to the guidelines with existing literature, the extraction form is designed to systematically collect original data across six key domains, including study characteristics, population characteristics, intervention details, analysis of costs and cost-effectiveness and clinical outcomes (table 3). The form will be piloted on a sample of five studies, with necessary refinements made through team discussion. Subsequently, data will be independently extracted by two teams, with cross-checking to ensure consistency. All extracted data will be managed using Microsoft Excel to support accuracy, transparency and traceability throughout the review.

sec.title: Quality assessment
sec.p: To ensure the methodological rigour and transparency of this systematic review, the quality of included studies will be assessed using the Consensus Health Economic Criteria (CHEC) list, which is specifically designed for systematic reviews of economic evaluations.26 It includes 19 items spanning domains such as study population, comparator description, research question, design, time horizon, cost and outcome measurement, incremental and sensitivity analysis, ethical considerations and funding transparency.26 Each item will be rated ‘Yes’ or ‘No/Unclear’. The proportion of ‘Yes’ responses for each item will be reported, accompanied by a descriptive summary to highlight the overall methodological strengths and limitations of the included studies.

To ensure objectivity and methodological accuracy, the quality assessments will be independently conducted and recorded by two separate reviewer teams. Disagreements will be resolved through discussion or arbitration by a third reviewer. The results of the quality assessment will be presented in summary tables and incorporated into the interpretation of findings. This assessment approach will improve the consistency, reliability and overall credibility of the research findings.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: This systematic review incorporates both economic and clinical outcome analyses (table 4). Cost data, including hospital- and patient-level expenditures, will be standardised and used to estimate overall costs and cost-effectiveness. Clinical outcome data will be initially synthesised through the narrative review. Additionally, where appropriate, meta-analysis, subgroup analysis and meta-regression will be employed to aggregate data and investigate sources of heterogeneity.

list-item.p: Distance travelled for examinations×cost per mile/km.

sec.title: Calculation for cost and cost-effectiveness
sec.p: To comprehensively assess the economic implications of POCUS in obstetrics, the narrative review will be initially applied to the estimated costs and cost-effectiveness associated with the implementation.

The cost data from all eligible studies encompassing both hospital-level expenditures, such as equipment acquisition, maintenance and staff training, and patient-level costs, including scanning fees and transportation, will be aggregated. For continuous data (eg, monetary cost values), means will be calculated to determine average expenses across studies. For categorical data (eg, frequency of certain types of costs and types of equipment purchased), proportions will be used to understand distribution. If applicable, SDs and CIs will be incorporated to evaluate the variability and precision of cost estimates. Average costs across distinct expenditure categories will then be synthesised to generate an overall estimate of the total cost associated with implementing POCUS in obstetric care.

To facilitate analytical comparability across studies and settings, a rigorous cost standardisation protocol will be implemented. All cost data will be converted into USD. Currency conversions will be based on the annual average exchange rate for the year in which the equipment was purchased (if reported) or the year in which the study was conducted. Historical exchange rate data will be retrieved from Exchange-Rates.org (available at https://www.exchange-rates.org/), a publicly accessible and regularly updated currency database. The converted cost will be calculated using the following formula:
In addition, historical cost data will be adjusted for inflation to reflect 2023 values, using the Consumer Price Index (CPI). The following formula will be used to standardise historical costs27:

CPI values will be obtained from the US Bureau of Labour Statistics database, which provides publicly accessible and annually updated inflation indices (available at https://www.bls.gov/cpi/data.htm). This approach allows for temporal and cross-national harmonisation of cost estimates and ensures that all financial data are expressed in a consistent, comparable format.

Subsequently, the cost-effectiveness of POCUS quantifies the additional cost per unit of health benefit achieved when using POCUS as opposed to alternative care models. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) is determined using the following formula:

mml:mrow.mml:mtext: Cost per patient using POCUS - Cost per patient using

sec.p: where ‘Cost’ refers to all related expenses for each care model. ‘Effect’ refers to measurable health outcomes. To ensure a comprehensive evaluation, the cost-effectiveness analysis will be conducted from multiple perspectives, including societal, healthcare system and patient-level viewpoints, to fully capture the economic and clinical value of POCUS in obstetric care.

To address the substantial heterogeneity in cost data across studies, a series of standardisation and preprocessing procedures will be implemented to enhance comparability and analytical rigour. First, all reported financial figures will be converted into a single reference currency using the most recent exchange rates for cross-country comparisons. Second, historical cost data will be adjusted for inflation and expressed in present-day values using appropriate deflators to account for temporal variations. Third, cost data will be normalised to a common unit of analysis, enabling meaningful aggregation and interpretation across studies.

However, despite the utility of such evaluations, heterogeneity in study populations, healthcare settings, comparator definitions and data collection methods can still substantially hinder the validity of pooled economic estimates.28 Variability in discount rates, currency conversions, perspectives adopted and methods used to generate utility measures further complicate comparability.28 Due to the above limitations, the meta-analysis of costs and cost-effectiveness estimates is rarely methodologically sound or meaningful.

sec.title: Meta-analysis for clinical outcomes
sec.p: To evaluate the clinical effectiveness of POCUS in obstetrics, a narrative synthesis of clinical outcome data will first be conducted. If at least five eligible studies are identified with comparable designs, populations, interventions and outcome measures, a meta-analysis will be performed to quantitatively synthesise the data. This threshold follows established methodological guidance, which suggests that pooling fewer than five studies may lead to low statistical power and unreliable heterogeneity estimates.29

For the calculation of pooled effect sizes, different statistical measures will be applied based on the type of clinical outcome. For continuous outcomes (eg, the number of antenatal care visits and the number of specific interventions), pooled estimates will be calculated using mean differences (MD) or standardised MDs, depending on the consistency of measurement scales across studies. For dichotomous outcomes (eg, institutional delivery rate and incidence of adverse outcomes), pooled estimates will be expressed as risk ratios with corresponding 95% CI.

Between-study heterogeneity will be assessed using Cochran’s Q test and Higgins’ I² statistic. A fixed-effect model will be applied when statistical heterogeneity is low, while a random-effects model will be used if heterogeneity is considered substantial (I² ≥50% or p≤0.10). All analyses will be performed using Stata V.18.0, with a two-sided p value of less than 0.05 considered statistically significant.

Substantial heterogeneity is anticipated given the expected variability in study contexts. One important source of variation lies in the healthcare delivery environment. Studies conducted in primary care clinics may differ markedly from those carried out in secondary or tertiary hospitals, particularly in terms of available resources, clinical protocols and patient profiles. Another contributing factor is the professional background of the personnel performing POCUS. For example, medical assistants or other forms of auxiliary healthcare staff may not possess the same level of clinical training as licensed obstetricians or radiologists, which can influence the consistency and accuracy of image acquisition and interpretation. Additionally, differences in ultrasound equipment are likely to affect outcomes. These contextual factors are expected to shape both the technical quality and clinical utility of POCUS interventions.

To account for these differences, subgroup analyses will be conducted to explore the influence of these contextual and clinical factors on pooled effect estimates. Subgroup stratification will include national income (LMICs vs high-income countries), level of healthcare delivery (primary, secondary or tertiary), operator profile (medical assistants without relevant formal training vs qualified practitioners), equipment specification (handheld vs cart-based or full-feature systems) and the risk level of pregnancy (high risk vs low risk).

Where data availability permits, meta-regression will complement subgroup analyses by quantitatively examining how multiple study-level covariates simultaneously influence effect sizes. Meta-regression extends traditional subgroup comparisons by modelling weighted linear associations between effect sizes and moderator variables, with regression coefficients representing the direction and magnitude of these associations.30 Key methodological procedures will include the use of restricted maximum likelihood estimation to account for between-study variance and Knapp-Hartung adjustments to improve the robustness of CIs, especially in the presence of limited studies or substantial heterogeneity.31 The goodness of fit will be evaluated using pseudo-R² statistics, and permutation tests will be conducted to minimise the risk of spurious associations.31 For continuous variables, covariates will be mean-centred to improve coefficient interpretability.31 Residual heterogeneity will be assessed by recalculating I² statistics after model fitting.31

To assess the robustness of the results, sensitivity analyses will be conducted, including leave-one-out procedures and exclusion of studies assessed as high risk of bias. Publication bias will be evaluated using funnel plots and Egger’s regression test. If bias is suggested, the trim-and-fill method will be used to adjust the pooled estimate accordingly.
As a systematic review protocol, the search strategy has been finalised, and the subsequent phases of the research are projected to be completed by August 2025.

sec.title: Ethics and dissemination
sec.p: Ethical approval is not required for this study, as this systematic review will rely exclusively on previously published and publicly available data. In addition, to ensure the credibility and methodological rigour of the review, all included studies and data will undergo formal quality assessment using validated tools, such as the CHEC list.

sec.title: Amendments
sec.p: This systematic review protocol will be amended during the peer-review process.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the context of persistently high MMR worldwide, POCUS has gained increasing relevance in obstetric care, particularly in resource-limited settings, due to its portability, accessibility and clinical versatility. Despite its growing utilisation, the cost and cost-effectiveness analyses of POCUS remain a subject of debate due to indirect and overlooked costs such as training, equipment maintenance and implementation. This systematic review aims to provide a comprehensive evaluation of the costs, cost-effectiveness and clinical outcomes of obstetric POCUS, highlighting its potential to improve maternal and neonatal health outcomes while contributing to more efficient use of healthcare resources.

The strength of this review is the rigorous methodology and balanced approach to evaluate the economic value of POCUS. By following the PRISMA 2020 guidelines and the PICOS framework, the study ensures a transparent, systematic and reproducible synthesis of the evidence. In addition, the application of the NHS Economic Evaluation Database Handbook and the CHEC list enhances the quality of data extraction and economic evaluation. This review advances previous research by integrating both clinical and economic perspectives, thereby providing a more comprehensive evaluation of POCUS in obstetric care. By adopting this dual-focus approach, the study enables a nuanced understanding of its impact across diverse healthcare settings, offering actionable insights for policymakers, health economists and clinical practitioners.

However, several limitations must be acknowledged. A primary challenge is the heterogeneity of cost data across different healthcare settings, which complicates direct comparisons. Variations in training costs, equipment maintenance and clinical practice patterns may limit the transferability of findings between contexts. To enhance comparability, monetary values should be standardised to a consistent currency. Future studies with standardised cost-reporting frameworks and detailed economic data are essential to improve cross-regional analyses. Furthermore, given the variability of available data, a formal meta-analysis may not be feasible due to cost and cost-effectiveness. Nevertheless, the narrative review could offer valuable insights by facilitating a broad and meaningful comparison of the existing evidence.

In summary, this systematic review protocol provides a comprehensive evaluation of the cost and cost-effectiveness of POCUS in obstetrics, offering a foundation for future research on its long-term economic and clinical impacts. With the development of POCUS, it holds significant potential to become an integral component of maternal healthcare globally, contributing to reductions in maternal and neonatal mortality and promoting greater health equity.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Prepublication history and additional supplemental material for this paper are available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2025-099121).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
